bug.author: KeAWang
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
Grid creation in the repo exceeds the grid bounds. Example:
gpytorch/test/examples/test_grid_gp_regression.py
Line 65 in db889f1
grid_bounds[i][0] - grid_diff, grid_bounds[i][1] + grid_diff, grid_size, device=device
and
gpytorch/gpytorch/variational/grid_interpolation_variational_strategy.py
Line 15 in 5411c90
grid[:, i] = torch.linspace(grid_bounds[i][0] - grid_diff, grid_bounds[i][1] + grid_diff, grid_size)
<denchmark-h:h2>To reproduce</denchmark-h>
Copying the code from the test case, we have <denchmark-code>import torch num_dim=1 grid_bounds = [(0, 1)] if num_dim == 1 else [(0, 1), (0, 2)] grid_size = 25 grid = torch.zeros(grid_size, len(grid_bounds)) for i in range(len(grid_bounds)): grid_diff = float(grid_bounds[i][1] - grid_bounds[i][0]) / (grid_size - 2) grid[:, i] = torch.linspace( grid_bounds[i][0] - grid_diff, grid_bounds[i][1] + grid_diff, grid_size ) </denchmark-code>
which returns the grid <denchmark-code>tensor([[-0.0435], [ 0.0018], [ 0.0471], [ 0.0924], [ 0.1377], [ 0.1830], [ 0.2283], [ 0.2736], [ 0.3188], [ 0.3641], [ 0.4094], [ 0.4547], [ 0.5000], [ 0.5453], [ 0.5906], [ 0.6359], [ 0.6812], [ 0.7264], [ 0.7717], [ 0.8170], [ 0.8623], [ 0.9076], [ 0.9529], [ 0.9982], [ 1.0435]]) </denchmark-code>
which clearly exceeds the grid_bounds. <denchmark-h:h2>Expected Behavior</denchmark-h>
I believe this should return a grid with all the points within the grid_bounds. This can be done by doing <denchmark-code>torch.linspace( grid_bounds[i][0] - grid_diff, grid_bounds[i][1] + grid_diff, grid_size ) </denchmark-code>
or <denchmark-code>torch.linspace( grid_bounds[i][0], grid_bounds[i][1], grid_size ) </denchmark-code>
instead.

comments.comment: This is actually intentional: we extend grids two points past the specified boundary. The reason for this is that when doing e.g. cubic interpolation over a grid you get pretty bad behavior around the "actual" boundary. Doing things this way ensures that users can never supply data near the "actual" boundary.
